one_liner: This technique detects and classifies anomalies in real-time using satellite sensor data.
how_it_works: The onboard anomaly detection method collects real-time sensor data from satellite systems and preprocesses it to eliminate noise. Machine learning algorithms are then applied to analyze the data, identifying deviations from normal operational parameters. Detected anomalies are classified into predefined categories, and alerts are generated for immediate attention.

steps: 1. Collect sensor data from satellite systems.
2. Preprocess the data to remove noise and irrelevant information.
3. Apply machine learning algorithms to analyze the data.
4. Identify deviations from normal operational parameters.
5. Classify the detected anomalies based on predefined categories.
algorithm.input_format: Real-time sensor data from satellite systems (e.g., time series data)
algorithm.output_format: Alerts and classifications of detected anomalies

parameters.name: threshold
parameters.effect: A lower threshold may increase sensitivity to anomalies but also raise false positives.

parameters.name: window_size
parameters.effect: Larger window sizes may smooth out noise but can delay detection.

parameters.name: learning_rate
parameters.effect: Higher learning rates can speed up training but risk overshooting optimal solutions.

complexity.time: O(n log n) for sorting and classification
complexity.practical_note: Real-world performance may vary based on the complexity of the machine learning model used.

use_when: Developing satellite systems requiring high reliability
Designing systems for harsh operational environments
avoid_when: When extensive post-launch maintenance is possible
In environments with stable and predictable conditions
implementation_skeleton:
def onboard_anomaly_detection(sensor_data: List[float]) -> Tuple[List[str], List[str]]:
    preprocessed_data = preprocess(sensor_data)
    anomalies = analyze(preprocessed_data)
    classifications = classify(anomalies)
    alerts = generate_alerts(classifications)
    return alerts, classifications
common_mistakes: Neglecting to preprocess data adequately, leading to noise interference.
Setting inappropriate thresholds that either miss anomalies or generate false alarms.
Failing to update the model with new data, which can lead to outdated classifications.

strengths: Real-time detection allows for immediate response to anomalies.
Machine learning improves accuracy over traditional methods.
Adaptable to various operational environments and conditions.
weaknesses: Requires significant computational resources for real-time processing.
Model performance may degrade if not regularly updated.
False positives can lead to unnecessary alerts and operational disruptions.
